November 27, 2019

Appr 1pm- 8pm 



Watch giant balloons slowly fill with helium at Macy\xe2\x80\x99s Thanksgiving Parade Balloon Inflation. Enter at Columbus Avenue & W. 73rd Street. Do not bring umbrellas, backpacks, large bags, alcoholic beverages, drones, or e-cigarettes. Free.



Tips for Making the Most of the Giant Balloon Inflation



Try to arrive at the viewing area early as this is a less crowded time. The balloons begin taking shape around 1pm-3pm, so this is a good time to visit. If you show up later in the evening, the crowds will be much larger though there will be more fully inflated balloons to see.



Admission to the viewing area ceases at 8:00 PM, so get your spot before then.



It\xe2\x80\x99s best to take public transportation to the balloon inflation area\xe2\x80\x94the crowds make parking nearby and access to the area by car difficult. The subway trains serving the balloon inflation area are the B or C trains to 72nd Street.



Given the size of the crowd, keep a close eye on children attending with you.



All spectators are subject to search by the NYPD.

Re: November 2019 NYC Events!
answers.body:
Giving back on Thanksgiving!



There are many organizations in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103465033', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC that welcome volunteers(local and non) for a few hours to help the less fortunate. You can help by prepping, serving or delivering meals to people in need.



A few that I can personally recommend:



-The Bowery Mission-You will need to sign up on Nov 1 @ 7am via Eventbrite(not confirmed yet but the last few years they used that platform) and select a time slot. The options fill up VERY fast. I mean, under 7 minutes fast. You would select a location and slot and go down for appr 3 hours.



I volunteer here every year so I can definitely recommend it:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



***********************



-City Meals on Wheels-Another option. You can get in contact with them and arrange to help with the prep or delivery of meals to those in need. Contrary to the org name, a vehicle is not needed. You will be paired with someone, if you choose to deliver, and given a manifest, cart with the meals and a general area to deliver.



This will usually take(if delivering) under 3 hours.



I usually do this for Christmas/NYE....but haven\xe2\x80\x99t for Thanksgiving. It\xe2\x80\x99s usually the same process when delivering.



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6holiday-meals



************************



Do know that there is an age restriction at the BM. Check if the same applies for CM.



(I have zero affiliation with either org. I have been involved with unpaid volunteer work as listed above and I have donated my unused clothing to them for many years).

Re: NY City in christmas and new year time...
answers.body:
(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103435125', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC public transit runs 24/7/365 but on Christmas and New Year's Day it will be the sunday/holiday schedule about half as often (for instance in Manhattan the train will run every 10 minutes versus every 5, with similar differences for overnight service).



Most things are open, although a few will close early Christmas Eve and be closed Christmas Day, a few New Year's Day. For instance, the ice rinks are all open, as are Central Park, Staten Island ferry, etc. But you really need to check the things you want to see/do.

Re: NY City in christmas and new year time...
answers.body:
Our favorite December in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103438694', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC \xe2\x80\x9cChristmas-window\xe2\x80\x9d stroll (around 3 hours walking) goes from Central Park down (south) on Fifth Avenue to around 48th Street viewing the lake and bridge in the Park (59th Street near 5th Avenue), the store windows at Bergdorf\xe2\x80\x99s (between 58th & 59th Streets) and SAKS (49th Street).....the "light show" on the SAKS front fa\xc3\xa7ade is not to be missed!, a stop in at St Thomas\xe2\x80\x99 (53rd Street) and St Patrick\xe2\x80\x99s (51st Street) to hear the bells and view the altars, watch the skaters at Rockefeller Center (between 49th & 50th Streets) and marvel at the Tree and then walk to Bryant Park behind the Library at 42st Street to shop at the Holiday Market. It may be a little chilly (dress warmly in layers), but it can be a delightful afternoon/evening! We generally stroll from north to south as the last stop at the Bryant Park Market allows folks to do some shopping for unique gifts.



CH

answers.title:
6.

Voyager, if you tell the forum where you\xe2\x80\x99re from that info relays key information, such as adaptability to cold, willingness to contend with street traffic, subways, crowds, your potential (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103438948', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC trip budget, restaurants wish list, potential hotel preferences, etc.

posts.title: \nOctober 2019 NYC Events!
posts.body:
(Original thread started by ztaks!)



Some pretty cool/huge events taking place in October:



Village Halloween Parade!



October 31, 2019/7pm

FREE....YES...you can march in the parade if you have a costume!

posts.title: \nGetting from Terminal 8 to Terminal 4 at JFK.
posts.body: I am flying into (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-83772622', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');JFK from Charlotte NC and arrive at 1130am at terminal 8. How do I get to terminal 4 for flight to India which leaves at 310 pm. Will there be enough time? I do realize I'll have to claim my bag at arrival and JFK and go through security again for my flight to India, Thank you in advance!

answers.title:
1.

Re: Getting from Terminal 8 to Terminal 4 at JFK.
answers.body: There is a (free within the airport) Airtrain for changing terminals. https:/\xe2\x80\xa6jfk-airport-map.html

answers.title:
2.

Re: Getting from Terminal 8 to Terminal 4 at JFK.
answers.body:
Usually they want you to check in for international (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-83773870', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');flights 3 hours in advance, which means only a few minutes after your first flight lands. You have 2 problems:



Luggage at JFK can be very slow - so you may wait an hour or more for your to turn up from the first flight



If there are any delays on your incoming flight you could end up with very little time to make the connection.



I would check the on time record of your incoming flight - but if it were me I would try to get an earlier flight.



Is this all one ticket so you are protected if you miss the flight to India - or will you have to buy a new ticket at the walk up price if you miss the flight for any reason?

answers.title:
3.

Re: Getting from Terminal 8 to Terminal 4 at JFK.

Re: The Ride vs Downtown Experience?
answers.body:
(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103470572', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');The Ride is an entertaining 90min ride. There are 2 animators inside the bus. The tour includes NYPL, Bryant Park, Grand Central, Chrysler Bldg, Madison Ave, Times Square,Columbus Square. The animators keep the passengers engaged with their scripted and some non-scrpted or impromptu jokes. There are 5-6 street performers dedicated to perform for "The Ride" passengers. The passengers can clearly hear the performers outside as their microphone is integrated with the speaker system inside the bus. Some pedestrians on the streets wouldn't have any idea that these performers are actually performing for "The Ride" passengers because their microphone is not loud enough to attract any attention from the street. Someone might think a random New Yorker is just talking to someone on his hand free phone, but he's actually rapping about anything or anyone he sees on the street. Quite entertaining for the spectators sitting inside the bus. For tourists like us, it's something different and we don't see these things on a daily basis so yeah, it's worth it. Every one had a good laugh. My young teens love it.



Downtown Experience is more of an informative tour about the history around Wall St, NY City Hall, Charging Bull, Black Slaves Cemetery, Supreme Court, Brooklyn Bridge, Battery Park, Broadway St, Canal St. The virtual goggle is an added gimmick to watch some re-enactment of scenes in the past that had happened in that particular area like first wave of European migrants etc...There's one street performer who's going to pop up during the tour. Some people find it a bad taste but our family enjoyed it. We did this tour right after our visit from One World Observatory & 9/11 Memorial. The meeting point is near the TKTS South St Seaport.



We had booked these tours as part of our Sightseeing Pass. We felt that it's worth it coz the tour gave us a different variety on our NYC sightseeing experience and a break from walking. We took this ride in early March so we stayed warm the whole time. It's a much better option than the open top decker Hop-On, Hop-Off Bus and Big Bus Tour. I find that native New Yorkers don't recommend these tours so much, but "The Ride" and "Downtown Experience" are both satisfying for us. Different strokes for different folks!

6.

answers.body:

So the deaths of 2,977 people is now something for tourists to \xe2\x80\x9cenjoy.\xe2\x80\x9d There is no way someone who would think that could be reasoned with.

Re: IRT train? Subway?
answers.body:
The Subway system at one time was run by three different companies: BMT, IRT, and IND. Many people still refer to lines based on their original companies. Your #1 train is on a line that was part of the IRT.

It's just the subway; you are better off just knowing the number of letter of the train.

Is it a house or an apartment; if it's an apartment, it's probably illegal for them to rent it out. But that's your decision.

answers.title:
5.

Re: IRT train? Subway?
answers.body: Post #4 explains the terminology well. The original companies were somewhat in competition and only showed their own routes on maps in the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103452931', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');cars. The Depression era Independent Line (IND) was run by the city, but lacked transfer points to other lines. Several of these were subsequently built. By 1940, the original IRT and BMT companies went bankrupt and merged into the IND.

answers.title:
6.

Re: IRT train? Subway?
answers.body: IRT stands for Interborough Rapid Transit, the name of the company that once owned and ran the 1,2,3,4,5, and 6 lines. Long after the lines were sold to the public authority many people still referred to them as "the IRT" and evidently some still do, based on what you have been told. (Nowadays, people usually just refer to "the 1 train," "the 6 train," etc) Something else you may hear oldtimers say is the "(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103453200', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Lexington Avenue" line and the "Seventh Avenue" or "Broadway" line. . Lexington Avenue refers to the 4,5 and 6 lines (6 also being known as "the local", while Seventh Avenue or Broadway means the 1 (local), 2 and 3 lines.

answers.title:
7.

Re: IRT train? Subway?
answers.body: Also, if staying in Kingsbridge, I suggest you also familiarize yourself with other forms of transportation, like buses. It's my impression there has been a lot of work (and some problems) on the 1 line in recent years, sometimes with people in the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103453262', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Bronx having to be bused to the nearest A train stop in northern Manhattan. There are also express buses that run in that area (2 or 3 times the cost of regular bus) and I would get the schedule for those as well.

It\xe2\x80\x99s a little expensive but not more than similar places all over the city. Figure about $150 for two.

posts.body:
Hello all

answers.title:

Re: We made it!!! On the go TR
answers.body:
Hi everyone, so this is my third attempt at this trip report it keeps disappearing on me , the first two were very detailed so unfortunately this one may not be as much, and it may be in two parts so I don't lose it again.

 We landed at (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103456440', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');JFK at 10:45 a.m., took the AirTrain ($5)to Jamaica Station, and then the Long Island Railroad(7.75) to Penn Station we arrived at our hotel at 1145. The original plan was to hopefully check in early and walk down 34th to catch the East River ferry over to Brooklyn spend a few hours there walk the bridge then the comedy show. Plans changed when we were unable to check in right away. I knew if we carried on with our plans we would not be back until now 11:45 p.m. So on to plan B. I've spent months planning, having a plan A plan B plan C if something goes wrong, thank goodness I did. On to plan B. We walked up Fifth Ave, went to the New York Public Library had a peek around in there for about 20 minutes, walkth rough Bryant Park over to Grand Central Terminal where we spent about 20 minutes looking around. Took a few pictures of the Chrysler Building popped in and out of a few shops, walked back to the hotel at 3:00 with fingers crossed that we were hopefully able to get in. As luck would have it we got in!!!!!!

We took our bags up to our room changed our clothes and headed out for the evening. I was determined to catch the East River ferry to Brooklyn so off to Penn Station we went, took the express Subway to South Battery Park and a quick 10-minute walk to pier 11 and we made it. It certainly was not the enjoyable 40-minute boat ride along the east side but it was 10 minutes and we were in Brooklyn. Winson Brooklyn we just walk to Grimaldi's enjoy the pepperoni pizza, FYI it is not licensed anymore. Hubby was dying for a beer so he was a little disappointed, but we sat enjoyed our pizza walked the Brooklyn Promenade made our way to the entrance of the Brooklyn Bridge

(Submitting now b4 i lose it again)

answers.title:
10.

Re: We made it!!! On the go TR
answers.body:
We walk the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103456499', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Brooklyn Bridge at about 6 p.m. the sun was to set around 6:20 but it remains light or entire walk. I was able to get some nice pictures and that's what it was about. Now I have walk the Brooklyn Bridge before so I know about people cutting out in front of the bikers and such but OMG was it ever horrible. It was all about the Selfies LOL. A few times I offered to take people's pictures for them because I could see that they were struggling to do so as do I when taking a selfie of my hubby and I! Lol the bridge took about 40 minutes to walk once we exited we were going to go to Canal Street. We made it there but we were getting chilly hubby still really wanted a beer so we stopped in Tribeca at some bar, he had a beer I had a ginger ale and we were good to go. Took a Subway up to Greenwich Village for comedy show at 9:30 we got to the Village around 8 found the place grabbed a coffee and did a walk around, again popped in and out of a few stores and went back to Fat Black Pussycat at 8:45 to wait for our show. There was six comedians one wasn't very good but the other five had us in tears laughing. A wonderful evening, not very expensive $60 four drinks total and the comedy show. That equals a good night in NYC!!! We have walked over 20 miles ( the Fitbit is coming up at 32 km wow) we are both fairly active people we walk all day for work so walking around shouldn't be a problem. I have been to New York a few times before so I was used to the people, how people cross at red lights,walk out in front of traffic, excessive horns on the taxicabs. The hords of people, Etc my husband on the other hand was not ready for that. He could not believe how many people cross the street on their cell phone and Dodge getting hit by cars every time. Look up people be careful!! His first subway ride experience was amazing there was a man on there playing his violin and singing and he was so good I was just in awe of him. I told my hubby it won't be like this every subway ride. So far it has been an amazing day in New York City I hate to call it a night but my body is tired and we have big plans for tomorrow. Tomorrow's goal is American Museum of Natural History, Central Park, Midtown. And Times Square by night.

Good night New York City till Tommorws adventures!!!!

posts.title: \nRenovation at Penn Station
posts.body:
After almost missing my (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103464525', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');flight out of JFK last night due to insane road traffic, I decide to give public transportation a try when going from/to the airport.



I heard that there is renovation at Penn Station. Have they shut down elevators or escalators? I travel with luggage and cannot use the stairs with it.

answers.title:
1.

Re: Renovation at Penn Station
answers.body:
Unfortunately --- I truly wish there were an easier way -- what you're going to need to do is to check the status of the elevators/escalators you plan to use, shortly before you use them. 

Here is a link to the page where you can check:

https:/\xe2\x80\xa6



In the first field, you'll put "34" and indicate from the drop down menu which one you want. Your choices are:

34 St - Penn - 1/2/3/LIRR

34 St - Penn - A/C/E



If you are taking the LIRR and/or the 1, 2, 3, choose that one. 

If you're taking the E, choose the second.



You will still need to leave a minimum of an hour ahead of the time you need to be at the airport, and I would leave even more (like 15 min. more) if it's rush hour.

answers.title:
2.

Re: Renovation at Penn Station
answers.body:
As far as I know, the renovation involves building a new entrance to the LIRR concourse from 33rd St. and 7th Ave. (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103465209', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Penn Station is a big place and there are often alternative escalators if one is out of service. Re: Cbd oil.
answers.body:
CBD oil may not be illegal as long as it has equal or less than 0.3% THC.



Thus it would be illegal to travel with CBD oil containing more than the quoted percentage above.



Personally, I would not travel with CBD oil internationally. There is no way for customs to quantify how much THC is in a bottle; thus they have the right to confiscate it if they see fit.



Here is a recent article on traveling with CBD oil : - 



https:/\xe2\x80\xa64ae7a59778af



You can also purchase it when you arrive:



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6nyc-fifth-avenue-bryant-park



https://www.thealchemistskitchen.com/

posts.title: \nESTA refund from third party affect future ESTA applications
posts.body:
Hi there,

I (stupidly) applied for an ESTA via third party website and as soon as i realised I applied through the wrong website (esta.us, was directed to usaesta.com when I began application), requested a refund. Full refund was granted quickly, but I'm now concerned about my ESTA status and applying for an ESTA via the official website. As it stands, the ESTA has been approved already according to the official website, but I have already been refunded the full amount that the unofficial website charged me...? So....

Has anyone had an experience with this? And what do I do? 

Does my approved ESTA still stand? 

So confused and worried.

Thank you so much for you help in advance.

answers.title:
1.

Re: ESTA refund from third party affect future ESTA applications
answers.body: If the official site confirms it is valid then you should be good to go, but if concerned, why not spend US$14 on another application with the official site, approval of which will cancel the previous one, and perhaps alleviate your concerns.

answers.title:
2.

answers.body:
I'm just concerned that the third party website has refunded me the full amount, my thinking being... does that mean they are requesting a refund from the official esta website/authority? which would mean my future applications will be denied? 

I think i will apply for a new one... i applied for through the third party website last night. will that cause me to be flagged?

ps. thank you so much for your help Frommy :)
Edited: 06 January 2018, 19:24

answers.title:
3.

Re: ESTA refund from third party affect future ESTA applications
answers.body:
If your application is showing up as valid at the official US site https://esta.cbp.dhs.gov/esta/ it may be OK..

However, for peace of mind, since these copycat sites are an ongoing problem you might want to contact them to ask. https:/\xe2\x80\xa6 

If you do get clarification it would be great if you reported back (these questions come up fairly often).

Re: ESTA refund from third party affect future ESTA applications
answers.body:
Hi everyone! Just wanted to update what has happened since the original post!

I was refunded quite promptly after e-mailing and requesting a refund. I also reapplied (myself) on the Official ESTA website very quickly after emailing and asking for a refund.

I landed in LA and had no issues with security. 

For everyone who reads this...

USE THE OFFICIAL ESTA WEBSITE!!!

save yourself the stress \xf0\x9f\x92\x9b 

Happy and safe travels everyone

"I landed in LA and had no issues with security."



The ESTA is not relevant when you arrive in the US, only when you go to board your aircraft to fly there, so no surprises you had no problem at LA.

For example, a modern chain type hotel popular with business travelers (say in places like Albany, Poughkeepsie & business hubs on Long Island and in Westchester) could be busy during the week but practically empty on the weekend. On the other hand, a cozy country inn might be quiet during the week but booked full way ahead for weekends.

posts.title: \nFirst timers!
posts.body:
Hello! This will be our first time traveling to nyc AND first time traveling with our 9month old son. Im looking for some itinerary help. I want to stay on the conservative side and not cram in too much in one day because I don\xe2\x80\x99t know how much our son will allow us to do. We will be traveling Nov 21-Nov 26. We arrive at 1pm on the 21st and leave at 10am on the 26th. So, given the above information, which of the following would you fit in/leave out, and what would the itinerary look like?



(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103464527', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Times Square 

Statue of Liberty

9/11 memorial 

Central Park 

Metropolitan museum

Brooklyn bridge 

Empire State Building 

Museum of natural history

Rockefeller plaza



I wish we had more time to experience all of NYC. I\xe2\x80\x99d love to see all the different neighborhoods/villages. I\xe2\x80\x99d also like to attend a broadway show but I know infants are not allowed. I also love any and all things Christmas so please let me know if there are any Christmas displays during the time of our visit that are worth seeing. I\xe2\x80\x99m very sad that the Christmas tree lighting ceremony won\xe2\x80\x99t be until December :( Anyway, thank you for all your help!

1.

You basically have 4.5 days in the city. You can see/visit everything on your list in that timeframe. 



Plot the attractions on a map and break each grouping into a specific day.

3.

Re: First timers!
answers.body: Are you ok with cold weather? You have lots of outdoor activities, temps could be in the 30s-40s and it's usually windy in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103464625', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC

4.

Re: First timers!
answers.body:
Just a head's up, if you are planning to take a taxi from the airport, know that in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103464789', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC it is not mandatory for cabs to carry car seats for children. You may wish to bring your own. Or you could arrange for one via a car service that will provide one, like www.kidcar.com.

AFAIK most airlines will not charge you to bring a car seat for the baby.

5.

Re: First timers!
answers.body: Good to know! Thank you!!

answers.title:
6.

Re: First timers!
answers.body: Where will you be staying. With an infant I would want to be sure you stay in a family residential area - rather than a business district or one primarily for trendy singles. Also what about transport - what sort of stroller are your bringing - or do you plan to rent one here?

answers.title:
7.

Re: First timers!
answers.body:
You have plenty of time to see all of you chosen sights. I guess having a lot of spare time is good in case the baby needs to go back to the hotel for a sleep or is grizzly.



Most people group these together. You could easily spread them out and do one or two per day.



- (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103468432', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Times Square, Rockefeller plaza. The lights at TS are the big drawcard. You might be able to go there after dinner for a while? I would also suggest Bryant Park and the NY public library this day, so Rockefeller Plaza plus those two sights. Bryant Park for the Christmas markets and iceskating, and the Library for indoor time and the Children's Room. The baby can toddle crawl/around in there.



- Statue of Liberty, 9/11 memorial, Brooklyn bridge. I would leave Brooklyn Bridge out in November if it's cold, seeing you have the baby. It can be really cold and windy there. See what the weather's like and if it's mild keep it in. Maybe even do it on another day so you can go in the middle of the day when it's warmer (but also more crowded). You have the time. Walk around Brooklyn Bridge Park for a while if it's nice out.



- Central Park, Museum of natural history, Metropolitan museum. Only do one big museum per day and spend time in Central Park with either of them. Both sides of the park have different scenery.



The Empire State Building can be done any night (I prefer it at night).

8.

10.

I was planning on bringing my own stroller and (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103469522', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');car seat but now that I think of it it seems like a lot to be carrying to/from airport and hotel. I also have no idea how to travel in between sites. I know it will be cold so I don\xe2\x80\x99t want to be walking everywhere with the baby. But taking a taxi would mean that I\xe2\x80\x99d have to carry our car seat everywhere we go? I don\xe2\x80\x99t know what to do.

posts.title: \nNew York prices
posts.body:
Hi all, 

Will be going on a short work trip in October and need some guidance as to how much to budget for the costs that I personally have to cover. Breakfast is included at the hotel. What is the price of an average deli-type lunch, a mid-range Italian dinner, a coffee to go, bottle of water, hot dog from a stand? Won\xe2\x80\x99t have time to shop but would like to source some Nike trainers for the (grown-up) kids. Any tips? Would really just like to get a handle on how much cash I will need. Thanks in advance!

answers.title:
1.

Re: New York prices
answers.body:
Avg deli type lunch can be had for $8. 

Bottle of water $1-2. 

Nike? Anywhere from $40 - $200 depending on the model. 

Mid range Italian dinner can be had for $45-60.

answers.title:
2.

Re: New York prices
answers.body:
If you are in midtown and don't want to hunt for the deals, A turkey sandwich on a roll with a soda will run about $12 to take out. In midtown, an average pasta dinner with one glass of cheap wine each would be around $80 for 2 with tax and tip. 

coffee at starbucks is 3-4. tap water is fine. I don't eat hotdogs so..

Id use yelp to filter by $ to find less expensive places. There are certainly lower priced options but they take time and patience.

DSW for discount sneakers.

answers.title:
3.

Re: New York prices
answers.body: Truth is, you can find almost anything you want at any price point. If you have a limited budget in mind, provide a ten block radius of where you want to be and what your dollar budget is, and recommendations at your price point can be made.

answers.title:
4.

Re: New York prices
answers.body: One thing - we don't recommend carrying a lot of cash. I usually bring $50-$100/day but I pre-pay most things before I arrive & put the rest on plastic.

answers.title:
5.

Re: New York prices
answers.body:
What do you mean by \xe2\x80\x9cdeli lunch\xe2\x80\x9d? 



Many use the term to mean \xe2\x80\x9ccorner store/bodega\xe2\x80\x9d which sell sandwiches and sometimes have food bars. Some use the term to mean a sit down restaurant such as (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103053165', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Katz\xe2\x80\x99s or Sarge\xe2\x80\x99s

answers.title:
6.

Re: New York prices
answers.body:
If your trip is work related, it seems like you would be focused in one particular area? Or will you be traveling around the city?. Some neighborhoods tend to be pricier than others for eating establishments. Some have a narrower range of options. Where will you be working and where is your hotel located?



For a mid range Italian dinner, what does that mean to you? A small plate of pasta and a salad with a bottle of mineral water? Or are you more likely to order a meat or seafood main, along with a first course or side dish, a glass or two of wine and dessert plus coffee? Or maybe something in between. It's really hard to predict what people will spend on food and drink.

answers.title:
7.

Re: New York prices
answers.body: Thanks so much for all your detailed replies. It\xe2\x80\x99s a huge help. I\xe2\x80\x99ll check on hotel location and be back with some more pointed queries:-)

answers.title:
8.

Re: New York prices
answers.body: I would do a search for, say, 'eating on a budget in NYC'. Once you know how cheaply you can eat, budget how much money to take accordingly.

answers.title:
9.

Re: New York prices
answers.body:
Your really should not worry so much about cash since you can pay for almost everything with a CCand that's what you should be doing to get the best rates of exchange.



Agree that you can eat at different price points but we don't know - per above - what you will eat. A sit down lunch is not $8 - that is getting a sandwich at a bodega and eating it on a park bench.



For perspective, when DH and I go to dinner at a casual local cafe we allow $90 for 2: one shared appetizer, 2 main courses (but not upscale like steak or lobster, usually chicken or pasta), one glass of house wine each, coffee, 9% tax and 20% tip.



Do understand that all prepared foods are taxed at 9% and anyplace you sit down to eat the waitperson or the bartender is tipped - 20% is the usual in nYC.



And whatever cash you have must be US $ - no one here wants foreign currencies - banks don't change them.



And remember you need a credit card for the hold the hotel will put on your room (usually $50 to $100 per night security deposit) that they return shortly after you check out.

answers.title:
10.

Re: New York prices
answers.body: Regarding lunch, I agree with #2 on sandwich costs. Also note that if you decide not to go deli route and opt for salad,sushi or other Asian type fast food place (think rice, noodle bowls), you could easily spend $10 - $20.

Re: Homewood Suites Times square New York
answers.body:
I have to say that the plate question confuses me, as well. I am pretty sure every hotel I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever stayed at that offered continental breakfast used plastic plates (and we stay at pretty nice hotels - not top of the line, but at least middle of the road). Why would that matter?

Re: Homewood Suites Times square New York
answers.body:
There are many biodegradable "plastic" products out there. What looks like a plastic cup can actually be cellulose. 

In NYC many places have different receptacles -- one for recycling, one for garbage. 

What is your concern? 

If you want a sit-down meal with table service, you'll get regular plates. But it sounds like table service at breakfast is not included in the price of your room.

answers.title:
5.

Re: Homewood Suites Times square New York
answers.body: Are you from the Uk? If so, hotel breakfasts aren't the same here. Most hotels don't have lovely sit down restaurants in them. They just have a space in or next to the lobby for a buffet, continental breakfast. We were in Ireland last Spring and couldn't get over the fancy restaurants inside the hotels we stayed in.

6.

Re: Homewood Suites Times square New York
answers.body: This hotel is not upscale. It does not have an on-site restaurant. The main advantage is space and location for the price point.

answers.body: If you are thinking of a large cooked breakfast that is served to you - you will need a much more upscale hotel. Budget/modest places typically have buffets with limited choices and there may not be anything hot - just cereals, yogurts, fruit, rolls/pastries and coffee/tea - yes, on plastic plates.

posts.title: \nGroupon vouchers ??
posts.body:
Has anyone used these , obviously you have 90 attractions to choose from , we want to do (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103445487', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Empire State , statue liberty Rockefeller, 911 

In which all these are included but I\xe2\x80\x99ve been told you have to book the Statue of Liberty and you won\xe2\x80\x99t be able to just turn up to use the voucher ?? Are these worth getting or not you seem to save a lot ? 

Can I have as much info as poss as it\xe2\x80\x99s 1st visit to New York City and don\xe2\x80\x99t want to waste any time thanks in advance

answers.title:
1.

Re: Groupon vouchers ??
answers.body:
FIrst, you would need to provide a link to the voucher you are talking about. Groupon offers many. 



Have you priced out the cost of booking direct vs purchasing the voucher? What is the cost of the voucher? Who is the actual company behind the voucher? Have you read the terms & conditions? 



You also have to factor in the time you will need to redeem the vouchers for actual attraction tickets, if needed.

answers.title:
2.

Re: Groupon vouchers ??
answers.body:
Those passes represent poor value for money. You will only be able to see very few of those 90 bundled offers and many will be of no interest. Furthermore, you are only getting vouchers and not tickets. Much better to decide on what you want to see/do and buy direct from the venue. groupon is a little different in that it does sell tickets - I bought (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103446754', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park bike rides for my family - and I buy from it for other purposes too.



For visits to Ellis Island/Statue of Liberty there is only one authorised reseller of tickets and that is Statuecruises - https://www.statuecruises.com/

answers.title:
3.

Re: Groupon vouchers ??
answers.body:
For places with timed tickets you risk not being able to get an immediate or convenient admission time when you exchange your voucher.

For the SOL/Ellis your voucher will get you a Reserve (Islands only) ticket - it is unlikely any Pedestal tickets will still be available. Crown tickets are never available same day

answers.title:
4.

Re: Groupon vouchers ??
answers.body:
For SoL/(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103451259', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Ellis Island same day tickets (NOT Pedestal which need to be bought 3-4 weeks in advance or Crown which need to be bout several months in advance) are Reserve only and are typically available for limited times which may not be when you want/need to go. If you can only get tickets for 2 pm or after you will have time to see only one island, not both. Also, you will need to stand on a long line (can easily be an hour) in order to change the vouchers you will get from the pass to tickets for the ferry. Expect the visit to be about 4 hours - for both islands and the 3 ferries.



Do remember that while the passes can save some money they can also waste a lot of your time and make a mess of you planned itinerary.

answers.title:
5.

Re: Groupon vouchers ??
answers.body:
For any timed ticket, such as an observatory or the (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103451719', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Statue of LIberty, I would purchase those separately and not use any pass.



If you want to explore discounts of the sights, one pass that most posters on the board like is the NYC GoCity Build Your Own Pass. It's driven by *your* choices, rather than presenting a plethora of places from which to choose. You choose three or more sights and get a discount of up to 20%.



One thing that no pass will tell you is that many sights have "pay what you wish" or free times. For instance, the Museum of Modern Art is free on Fridays from 4-8. The American Museum of Natural History is always "pay what you wish," although if you'd like to go to the IMAX theater or Hayden Planetarium or any special exhibit, you must pay full price (and then perhaps a fee on top). The New York Historical Society is pay what you wish on Fridays from 6-8. The Bronx Zoo is free on Wednesdays, and so on.



So I would get a good guidebook first, see what your options are, make a list of the absolutely must see/must do's, then check out their websites to see if they have any free or "pay what you wish" hours. Then use a Build Your Own Pass for the rest.
Edited: yesterday, 00:20

answers.title:
6.

answers.body: Thankyou

answers.title:
7.

Re: Groupon vouchers ??
answers.body: Thanks for advice !

Look at the Build Your Own Pass. You just choose what you want to see, not 90 or hundreds of sights like other passes. You get a discount on each entry fee.



https:/\xe2\x80\xa6build-your-own



It would be difficult to do more than or two sights per day, so having a huge amount of sights on a pass doesn't make sense.

Regarding the \xe2\x80\x9cChristmastime in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-97365782', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC\xe2\x80\x9d thread with the 2018 dates: keep in mind that Thanksgiving 2018 was Thursday, November 22nd, the earliest possible date. Thanksgiving 2019 will be Thursday, November 28th, the latest possible date. 



You\xe2\x80\x99ve booked your stay over Thanksgiving weekend, did you realize that?



Because Thanksgiving is the start of the holiday season, many of the dates in the \xe2\x80\x9cChristmastime in NYC\xe2\x80\x9d thread for 2018 may be pushed out by ~6 days in 2019. No dates are confirmed yet, but this is what you should plan for at this point. 



For example, if a store window, Chistmas tree, holiday market, etc usually unveils/lights up/opens a week before Thanksgiving, in 2018 that was November 15th and in 2019 that won\xe2\x80\x99t be until November 21st. 



That said, most Christmas things are up/on/open by Thanksgiving Day. One big exception is the Rockefeller Center tree, which is typically lit the Wednesday after Thanksgiving. If they stick to that, the tree won\xe2\x80\x99t be lit in 2019 until Wednesday, December 4th. 



Thanksgiving is a fun time to be in NYC, and there\xe2\x80\x99s a thread for that, too, though I can\xe2\x80\x99t link it right now, sorry. If you\xe2\x80\x99re on the full website, you can look in the forum top questions section. 



Happy planning!

answers.title:
6.

posts.title: \nScooter Rental in Central Park?
posts.body:
Hi



I have searched, and it seems there's no Lime or Bird or electric scooter rental in central park. 



Most of the bike rental places online don't have electric or non electric scooters for rent, only bikes. 



My kids are much more comfortable on scooters than bikes... and with the summer crowds, I'm sure they'd be annoying to most people. 



Is there any way to rent an electric scooter in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-101367727', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park, and if not, just a regular scooter? (Not a mobility)



Thanks!

answers.title:

Re: Scooter Rental in Central Park?
answers.body: Unfortunately, there are some in the NY City Council who are urging that electric scooters be approved. I don't know if they are in the pocket of Silicon Valley, or if they are deluded about "handicapped access" versus reckless duuuudes. Just allowing personally owned electric scooters on public roads (with no license plates, which used to be the sticking point) was a crazy idea. They are no more willing to stop at red lights than bicyclists are.

answers.title:
6.

answers.title:

Re: Scooter Rental in Central Park?
answers.body: Ordinary human powered bicycles are restricted to the outer roadways and anything machine powered would have similar restrictions if allowed at all. (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-101369910', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park is best seen by foot as mentioned.

answers.title:
8.

Re: Scooter Rental in Central Park?
answers.body: Electric scooters are considered vehicles and are allowed only on public highways - not on sidewalks, not on pedestrian paths and not in parks - except places where a (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-101372713', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');car would be - essentially nowhere. The city council considering approval of their use is a terrible idea. They are not appropriate for the traffic in NYC and people will end up using them illegally in the wrong places and causing numerous accidents and injuries. Central Park is primarily for pedestrians - and bikers on the very limited bike trails. If your kids can't manage bikes for some reason they should stick to walking.

answers.title:
9.

Re: Scooter Rental in Central Park?
answers.body: Also, a bonus that you can\xe2\x80\x99t use scooters is that you won\xe2\x80\x99t have to bring any helmets for the family to use the scooters, as riding scooters on roads (as they are supposed to be ridden) is even more dangerous without a helmet :)

answers.title:
10.

Re: Scooter Rental in Central Park?
answers.body:
Motorized scooters are a nightmare anywhere, let alone in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-101373487', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Park, where the roads go around bends full of trees, so that neither you nor the people around those corners can see you. Bikers who are doing the equivalent of "ambling" are annoying for the professional bikers and racers who use the park daily. I can't even imagine what a mess it would be to add scooters with little kids on them. Frightening! 



The obvious question would be "And are they going to mandate helmets"? If CitiBikers are permitted not to wear them, scooter riders probably wouldn't have to either. Simply a terrible idea.



Coming from the sibling of a person who was riding a bike safely in NYC and was hit by an irresponsible motorist.

posts.title: \nItinerary Help: Realistic? Thanksgiving week
posts.body:
Hi. Wondering if I am packing in too much...Me, husband, 13 year old daughter. Have been to (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103438543', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC once before. Primary reason for this visit is Thanksgiving Day Parade.

11/25: Arrive 1045am. Hotel at 7th ave & 55th st. Subway to grand central station and its holiday market. Walk to Mood fabrics, walk through Times Square back to hotel.

11/26: 9/11 museum (daughter\xe2\x80\x99s first choice of what to see in nyc), Staten Island ferry, museum of Chinese in America. Mode of transportation tbd.

11/27: Metropolitan Museum (we\xe2\x80\x99re ok with seeing what we can see in 3-4 hours) balloon inflation, Wicked at 7pm. Mode of transportation tbd.

11/28: Parade, Central Park. Walking.

11/29: depart at 1140am (sad face)



Thanks for any opinions. I feel out of my element planning this trip...NYC is so different from MN.

answers.title:
1.

Times Square is the heart of the Theater District & it's best seen at night.

answers.title:
2.

answers.body: Brilliant choice to go to the Met the morning of balloon inflation. It is "relatively" quiet. Most people hang out at (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103438921', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');the Museum of Natural history. It's a nice walk across the Park when you leave the Met.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Itinerary Help: Realistic? Thanksgiving week
answers.body:
Just a note to say that the 9/11 Museum is very graphic, and is an emotionally intense experience for most adults, let alone children. You might want to do (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103439097', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');the Museum of the Chinese in the Americas first, then make your way to the 9/11 one. 

Personally I do not recommend the museum for anyone under 18, because at that point they've reached the age of majority and can make their own decisions. It is built on the footprint of the two towers, the scene of a mass murder.

The Staten Island Ferry might be one way to "decompress" after the Museum. Something about the lull of the sea can be comforting.

The 9/11 Museum is a must if you are in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103445646', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC and have the opportunity to visit, even at 13. She will learn a lot in those 3+ hours and come out with a better understanding of the events of that day.

Re: Itinerary Help: Realistic? Thanksgiving week
answers.body:
11/25: After (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103447249', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Grand Central Terminal, I would suggest a stop at the New York Public Library to visit the original Winnie the Pooh & Friends and then a visit to the Christmas Market at Bryant Park.

11/26: Note that taking the Staten Island Ferry you have to disembark and re-embark, you cannot just stay on to come back, you might consider a cruise instead which goes closer to the Statue of Liberty (check out Circle Line and Sail NYC)

11/27: as mentioned, you will see Times Square after Wicked, so I would move that visit from November 25 to this day.

Re: Itinerary Help: Realistic? Thanksgiving week
answers.body: On Thanksgiving I don't see that you have reserved a Thanksgiving lunch or dinner - or will you just do casual? Also you seem to be spending the entire day on your feet - and it seems like you might be incredibly worn out after the early start for the parade.

answers.title:
8.

Re: Itinerary Help: Realistic? Thanksgiving week
answers.body:
>>On Thanksgiving I don't see that you have reserved a Thanksgiving lunch or dinner<< Most restaurants don't take reservations more than 30 days ahead, even for Thanksgiving. So no worries that you don't have plans yet. You do want to think about it soon though.



The Grand (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103452448', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Central Holiday market is relatively small and surprisingly "upscale" with high quality jewelry and crafts. Think $200 cutting board or $80 dog sweater... It's still nice to see but make sure you know what to expect. The Bryant Park holiday market is larger, is more picturesque, it has more things to purchase for modest prices. Some might say it has more "junk" compared to Grand Central. It depends on your perspective. It's more than just mass produced trinkets. You can aim to do both that night. The Bryant Park one also has ice skating and food stalls.



BTW, it's only a 20 minute walk from your hotel to Grand Central, with interesting things to see along the way. No need to take the subway unless weather is lousy or someone has walking limitations.



For your next day, in conjunction with the Museum of Chinese in America, I would plan to stroll around Chinatown then up through Soho. Continue to Greenwich Village if you have the time and energy. 



For Balloon Inflation day, the NYPD shuts down exits from the park near the AMNH. If you walk across the park, you may find that you have to detour a good distance south until you can exit the park, then follow the guided crowds back north towards the balloon inflation. It's surprisingly well organized but you have to do it their way!



Allow PLENTY of time to get through Balloon inflation and back down to the theater district.



On Thanksgiving day, plan more than just the parade and Central Park. There are a variety of things open, including Top of the Rock and Empire State Building. It could be cold and after spending all morning outside staking your spot for the parade, you may not want to follow it up with a day outdoors in the park.

answers.title:
9.

Re: Itinerary Help: Realistic? Thanksgiving week
answers.body:
The balloon inflation is getting bigger and bigger each year. Allow plenty of time just to get to the entry point and then to look at the balloons.



You can't just walk down Centrtal (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103453699', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Park West to the entry point from the AMNH.. There is a big detour from the AMNH over to Columbus Ave at the back of the museum right down to 73rd St. (That was the process last year, it should stay the same this year). There are lots of people and the NYPD directing everyone.



You might get some info about the balloon inflation and the entry process from this information piece:



https://www.tripadvisor.com.au/ShowTopic-g60\xe2\x80\xa6
Edited: yesterday, 03:16

10.

posts.title: \nDaniels NYC
posts.body:
Okay, so I leave for (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103467007', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');New York in 24 hours and I have a reservation at Daniels NYC with a girlfriend.



Question, I was going to wear a black sleeveless blouse with grey plaid print dress pants and nice suede ankle boots. I plan on also adding bling. Thought would that be appropriate for the dress code? 



I lost a lot of weight and that\xe2\x80\x99s all that in my closet that nice that fits.

answers.title:
1.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body:
Sure, that will work.



A lot of women may be in cocktail attire (dresses), but what you are planning sounds fine. If you're really concerned and want to up it just a tad, you can consider pumps instead of boots. But what you described will be fine. Bon Apetit!



(Note: it's (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103467087', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Daniel, no "s".)

answers.title:
2.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body:
Risa is more of a fashion maven than I and maybe I'm old fashioned BUT..from a practical standpoint, a sleeveless blouse sounds like you may be cold (without a jacket over it) and while I know plaid is currently in fashion, it just doesn't strike me as dressy enough. Unless you,re going on your first night, maybe use this visit as an opportunity to buy yourself something new, Most women will either be wearing dresses or solid color pants.. OR, get a nice blazer to go over what you plan. A black velvet blazer is a useful wardrobe piece anyway.



All that said, they will not turn you away.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body: A nice blazer or jacket at the very least, it's cold out there. Helps dress up the outfit. And a good excuse to go shopping.

answers.title:
4.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body:
Ok, this is totally a style thing. I am always uncomfortable in blazers. I rarely wear them (I wore an old Escada blazer last week with a big shawl as an in-between jacket, but it's rare for me). And I don't think they dress up an outfit at all - I'm not a fan or the so called dressy jacket with sparkles or rhinestones or even velvet. The day I start wearing those, morphine me, they're aging. There is no right or wrong here, so I'm not saying nywhiz or WEQ is wrong - it's personal preference. But the last thing I would wear to an elegant evening is a blazer. I would go sleeveless with probably a sparkly cuff bracelet. If you're cold, a cashmere sweater to throw over your shoulders could work.



When it's cold, I have those arm gloves that I usually take off, but sometimes (rarely) make part of the outfit. I go sleeveless in restaurants or parties all year long. 



i'm taking you at your word that the pants are dress pants. Under similar circumstances, if not a dress, I would be in wide leg solid black pants (and spike-y heels). But I understand that when you're losing weight you don't want to buy anything until you're settled on your new weight. 



In any event, just enjoy and don't worry.

answers.title:
5.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body:
Blazer? jacket? (semantics). Something to cover up in cold weather. There are some extremely "stylish" ones out there (I'd refrain from using the term chic). Yes, it is a matter of personal taste. That's what I wear to cover what's below. And an option for the OP.

Like NYWhiz, I am "old" and always cold. I have to have something to throw over the shoulders etc., even inside the restaurants, unless one is in Europe where AC's are rare.

answers.title:
6.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body: I use blazer and jacket interchangeably. It\xe2\x80\x99s completely a style thing and no right or wrong. I just don\xe2\x80\x99t want OP to think she \xe2\x80\x9cneeds\xe2\x80\x9d a blazer/jacket to be dressed appropriately.

answers.title:
7.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body: Today I wore a rain jacket, wool hat and scarf. It's cold out there. You might want to bring a beautiful wrap to dinner. I like velvet jackets, if they're cut well and do something for you. I wouldn't be caught dead anywhere in a sleeveless blouse at this time of year -- I'm one of those who's always cold. But if *you're* comfortable, that's all that matters. Great jewelry never hurts, either.

answers.title:
8.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body:
Of course, she can. But since she asked (opinions of strangers who only have their imaginations to work with) IMO, she needs something to "top up" that look. I have a hard time picturing plaid as "dressy" unless it is some kind of silk? Or has a "dress stripe" running on the sides.

In the end, the table is reserved. It's hers.

answers.title:
9.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body: I agree that you need something to cover your arms like a sweater or jacket. Not only is it getting cool out but I've been in restaurants on really hot summer days & froze to death because I was in short sleeves & the a/c was cranking. I'm not too much into what kind of cover (for me a basic black cardigan would do) but I do think cover will be useful for your own comfort.

answers.title:
10.

Re: Daniels NYC
answers.body:
It's past AC weather - we are now chilly, esp at night. Definitely you need a jacket outdoors and I would be wearing some sort of cover up indoors rather than bar arms.



As for plaid pants - well it's up to you. But are you talking a black/white check or some sort or bright multi-colored plaid? And black is always correct.

posts.title: \nWhich Sport?
posts.body:
Hey everyone



So, I know that this may invite lots of different opinions, but I guess I'm looking for the majority opinion.



I'm from the UK and visiting America/(ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103435331', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');NYC for the first time in February and I'd like my family and I to see a game of.... something!



Forgive my ignorance but I'm assuming the big three sports are baseball, basketball and American football.



If my family and I (including kids aged 15 and 9) were to book tickets to see a game, which sport is easiest to follow and most entertaining, for the kids especially?



Thanks in advance.

answers.title:
1.

Re: Which Sport?
answers.body:
Your options will be basketball and hockey...both of which are easy to follow. 



What are your dates?

answers.title:
2.

Re: Which Sport?
answers.body:
Football will be finished and baseball doesn;t start until April (way too cold to play outdoors in midwinter)



For baseball there are 2 teams - Knicks (MSG) and Nets (Barclay Center in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-103436046', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Brooklyn) and for hockey 3: Rangers at MSG, Devils in NJ and Islanders in various locations (Barclay or out in Nassau). Have the watch parts of a game for each and see what interests them. 



I love basketball and find hockey terminally boring - but it's all personal choice.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Which Sport?
answers.body:
There's a typo above. The Knicks and Nets are basketball. The NBA season is just beginning now. The Knicks are expected to be bad and they look that way so far. The Nets are contenders this year. By February a Nets game is likely to be more exciting than a Knicks game. 



Personally, I prefer hockey. Think of it as soccer on ice with unlimited substitutions (including substitutions without stopping play). The game is pretty intense throughout and hockey fans are very involved.

4.

only two sports that time of the month. Basketball and hockey.

posts.title: \nIs hotels.com reliable
posts.body: Has anyone used this site before? Is it legit? I've found better deals on there but I don't want to book through them without any feedback. Did you have problems checking in to a hotel when you went?

answers.title:
1.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: Very reliable. But as with any site you might want to contact the hotel directly to see if they'll do better than the price quoted on the third-party site.

answers.title:
2.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: I never had a problem but after the reservation is "confirmed" through any on line site I wait about 2 hours then call the hotel directly.

answers.title:
3.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: I've booked rooms through hotels.com at least a dozen times with no problems. Agree with above about checking directly with hotel in case you can get a better rate and always pay attention to the cancellation policy.

answers.title:
4.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: It has a good reputation. Just read all of the fine print to understand the cancellation policy for whatever you are booking, and whether the hotel has extra fees they charge.

answers.title:
5.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: I think hotels.com has gotten pretty good about showing those extra fees - I was just looking at rooms in (ta && ta.queueForLoad ? ta.queueForLoad : function(f, g){document.addEventListener('DOMContentLoaded', f);})(function(){ta.trackEventOnPage('postLinkInline', 'impression', 'postLinks-86441263', '');}, 'log_autolink_impression');Vegas and right under the price it says "excludes daily resort fee". But definitely always check so there are no surprises!

answers.title:
6.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: Hotels.com is the same company as Expedia, which also owns Hotwire. Expedia and Priceline (which owns Booking.com) are the two big players in the online travel marketplace. Reliable, yes - but I would always try to book directly and, if you see a better price on the site see if the property will match it.

answers.title:
7.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body:
From what I understand, Hotels.com is on par with the other well-known third-party booking portals. The big question, however, is why use a third-party booking portal in the first place if you can book directly with the hotel for the same or a lower price? I have yet to book directly with a hotel that wasn't willing to match the quote from a third-party, and many hotels have a low price guarantee if you book direct through the hotel's website. Indeed, with rare exceptions, I have found that the price quote on the hotel's website is the same or lower than the price from the third-party vendor after verifying that the room and all applicable fees are identical. 



I have also found that third-party booking sites are fine when everything goes right with the reservation, but not so fine when things go wrong, such as a room that does not match the description on the reservation, a room that looks into a dumpster or air shaft , or an unexpected charge on the invoice. In my experience, and from what I have learned from people in the hospitality industry, hotels are much more likely to move the guest to a different room, offer an upgrade, offer perks, or waive fees to resolve problems if the guest booked directly with the hotel (particularly if the guest participates in the hotel's rewards program), than it is if the guest booked through a third-party.

answers.title:
8.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body:
Well of course, since the hotel is making more money off that guest since they don;t have to give a cut to the booking service. The question is if the hotel will match the same deal.



And key is reading the small print and understand when you have to cancel to avoid paying a penalty.

answers.title:
9.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body: I always use booking.com and hotels.com and also check hotel site as well. I continue to monitor all and watch for special discount emails. And have frequently reduced my initial rate.

answers.title:
10.

Re: Is hotels.com reliable
answers.body:
I've re--booked the same hotel for the same dates 3 times now for our upcoming trip. First on the hotel's site (AAA rate), again when that rate dropped slightly, and now I just re-booked on Booking.com because they had a VERY substantial sale, much lower than the hotel's website. 



The only time I've asked for a price match with third party the answer was "no". That might not always be the case, but rates are computerized, etc. Plus there could be contractual things involved that prevent the hotel from matching if they push a special promotional sale with a third party site. That's just speculation. It does not surprise me that hotels may not always be able to match the rate they give to a third-party site to promote the hotel.



I have mixed feelings about third-party sites. I have never been disappointed with them, but it sometimes feels "right" to book directly and I wonder if I will be able to get a better room. Who knows... I often book directly these days.



The plus side of booking with a third-party site is that it is easier to find your booking details, especially if you booked a couple of options, and you are going through their security process to submit your cc info, etc instead of the hotel's own website. Some of those websites are rinky-dink. Even for those that are more professional, do they really have the same security as the giant players like Expedia, Hotels.com, etc? I doubt it but I have no first-hand info to back that up.
